section.title: Unreached code analysis
section.para: enables a flow analysis check to detect unreachable code. It is possible to assert that a statement is reached or not reached by preceding it by a keyword introduced by one of the directives:
section.programlisting: #pragma TenDRA keyword identifier for set reachable #pragma TenDRA keyword identifier for set unreachable
section.para: The fact that certain functions, such as exit, do not return a value can be exploited in the flow analysis routines. The equivalent directives:
section.programlisting: #pragma TenDRA bottom identifier #pragma TenDRA++ type identifier for bottom
section.para: can be used to introduce a typedef declaration for the type, bottom, returned by such functions. The TenDRA API headers declare exit and similar functions in this way, for example:
The bottom type is compatible with void in function declarations to allow such functions to be redeclared in their conventional form.

section.title: Variable flow analysis
section.para: enables checks on the uses of automatic variables and function parameters. These checks detect:

listitem.para: If a variable is not used in its scope.
If the value of a variable is used before it has been assigned to.
If a variable is assigned to twice without an intervening use.
If a variable is assigned to twice without an intervening sequence point.

section.para: as illustrated by the variables a, b, c and d respectively in:

The second, and more particularly the third, of these checks requires some fairly sophisticated flow analysis, so any hints which can be picked up from exhaustive switch statements etc. is likely to increase the accuracy of the errors detected.

In a non-static member function the various non-static data members are analysed as if they were automatic variables. It is checked that each member is initialised in a constructor. A common source of initialisation problems in a constructor is that the base classes and members are initialised in the canonical order of virtual bases, non-virtual direct bases and members in the order of their declaration, rather than in the order in which their initialisers appear in the constructor definition. Therefore a check that the initialisers appear in the canonical order is also applied.
It is possible to change the state of a variable during the variable analysis using the directives:
section.programlisting: #pragma TenDRA set expression #pragma TenDRA discard expression
section.para: The first asserts that the variable given by the expression has been assigned to; the second asserts that the variable is not used. An alternative way of expressing this is by means of keywords:
section.programlisting: #pragma TenDRA keyword identifier for set #pragma TenDRA keyword identifier for discard variable
section.para: respectively. These expressions can appear in expression statements and as the first argument of a comma expression.

warning.para: The variable flow analysis checks have not yet been completely implemented. They may not detect errors in certain circumstances and for extremely convoluted code may occasionally give incorrect errors.

section.title: Variable hiding
section.para: can be used to enable a check for hiding of other variables and, in member functions, data members, by local variable declarations.

section.title: Exception analysis
section.para: The ISO C++ rules do not require exception specifications to be checked statically. This is to facilitate the integration of large systems where a single change in an exception specification could have ramifications throughout the system. However it is often useful to apply such checks, which can be enabled using the directive:

This detects any potentially uncaught exceptions and other exception problems. In the error messages arising from this check, an uncaught exception of type ... means that an uncaught exception of an unknown type (arising, for example, from a function without an exception specification) may be thrown.
